subject: Creativity
title: Nature Exposure and the Attention Restoration Effect
description: Learn Nature Exposure and the Attention Restoration Effect in one minute.

hook.text: Four days in nature with no technology improved creative problem-solving by 50% in a 2012 study.

buildup.text: Attention Restoration Theory explains why: nature provides 'soft fascination' that lets directed attention rest.

discovery.text: Urban environments demand constant directed attention (traffic, signs). Nature lets it recover.

twist.text: Even 15 minutes in a park helps. You don't need a wilderness expedition â€” a garden view is enough.

climax.text: Japanese 'forest bathing' (shinrin-yoku) lowers cortisol by 16% â€” reducing the stress that blocks creativity.

punchline.text: Nature doesn't inspire creativity. It removes what blocks it.

quiz.question: By how much did four days in nature improve creative problem-solving?
